resources.string: Press Start when you are ready to count your pulse!
Heart Rate (in Beat Per Minute or BPM), is measured by taking your pulse : measurement can be done by putting two fingers on your wrist or your neck.

In History tab, Heart Rate values are shown as % of your HR Max, HR Max is your maximum Heart Rate, it's calculated with Astrand method (220 - age for men, and 226 - age for women).

 Following are the three main types of Heart Rate (HR):
 - HR Min: Heart Rate at rest,
           taken after waking up
 - HR T: Heart Rate during a training,
           taken between two efforts
 - HR Max: Maximal Heart Rate,
           taken after an intensive effort

 Following are seven types of activity: with corresponding references, % of HR Max, speed (s) and duration (d)
 * RESTING: < 42%, s=0, t=∞
 * RUNNING: 65-75%, s≈11km/h, d≈3 hours or more
 * MARATHON: 75-80%, s≈11km/h, d≈3 hours 30 minutes
 * SEMI-MARATHON: 80-85%, s≈12km/h, d≈1 hour 45 minutes
 * SPEED 10 km/h: 85-90%, s≈10km/h, d≈1 hour
 * SPEED HIGH: 90-95%, s≈15km/h, d≈6 or 7 minutes
 * SPEED HIGH +: 95-100%, s≈16 km/h, d≈5 minutes or less

 You can find your personalized HR Zones in the third tab. They give you an idea of HR to maintain, depending on the activity (resting, marathon, etc.).
HR zones are based on your profile (age, sex, HR Min and HR Max), they are determinated using:
 * the Astrand method, when you don't have any measurement yet
 * the Karvonen method once your profile is filled-out and you have some measurements

 Physical exercise reduce your pulse at resting, and it does not really influence HR Max.
 Checking your pulse is very important to track your athletic progression: the more you train, the lower your Heart Rate will be.

* Give us your feedback!

* Ask for new feature!
